title: Japanese Chapter 1 Quiz: The Japanese Writing System

questions.question: How many writing systems does Japanese use?
questions.explanation: Japanese uses three writing systems: Hiragana, Katakana, and Kanji.

questions.question: Which Japanese script is used for native Japanese words and grammatical elements?
questions.explanation: Hiragana is used for native Japanese words and grammatical particles.

questions.question: Which Japanese script is used for foreign words and onomatopoeia?
questions.explanation: Katakana is used for foreign loanwords and onomatopoeic expressions.

questions.question: Which Japanese script is borrowed from Chinese characters?
questions.explanation: Kanji characters were borrowed from Chinese and represent meaning.

questions.question: In which direction do Japanese people typically read text?
questions.explanation: Modern Japanese is typically read left to right, top to bottom, though traditional vertical writing still exists.
questions.correctAnswer: Left to right, top to bottom
options: Right to left, top to bottom
Left to right, top to bottom
Top to bottom, right to left
Bottom to top, left to right

questions.question: Form the Japanese sentence for "I am a student"
questions.explanation: This is a basic Japanese sentence using the copula です (desu) meaning "to be."

questions.question: What is the main purpose of Hiragana in Japanese writing?
questions.explanation: Hiragana is used for native Japanese words and grammatical particles like は, を, に, etc.
questions.correctAnswer: To write native Japanese words and grammar
options: To write native Japanese words and grammar

questions.question: Form the Japanese sentence for "This is a book"
questions.explanation: これ (kore) means "this" and 本 (hon) means "book."

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a Japanese writing system?
questions.explanation: Romaji is the romanization of Japanese using Latin alphabet, not a native Japanese writing system.

questions.question: Form the Japanese sentence for "I am going to school"
questions.explanation: This follows the basic Japanese sentence structure: Subject + は + Object + に + Verb.
